Introduction


Prior research has found five video elements that impact a viewer's streaming experience of a video. On this page, we introduce you to the five video elements and how each of them affects your viewing experience:

(1) Video resolution
(2) Audio quality
(3) Motion smoothness
(4) Audio stability
(5) Audio-video syncronization.

Please read this page carefully to understand how we define these elements. A small quiz will follow this page.

Video resolution


This refers to how clear or crisp the visuals are in the video. They can be degraded due to the limited data being transmitted to your device.

   

Compare the two videos. The higher resolution the imagery is, the crispier and clearer the video looks, as shown on the left. When a video has low-resolution imagery, the video can be pixelated and unclear, just like the clip on the right.


Audio quality


The second feature, audio quality, is similar.


   

With high-quality audio, voices are clear and crisp, as shown in the first audio clip on the left. The lower the audio quality, the more muffled and unclear the voice sounds, as you can hear in the second audio clip on the right.


Motion smoothness


Motion smoothness refers to how smooth the visuals of the video are.

   

In the video on the left, the video imagery plays smoothly. When there is limited internet bandwidth, some information would be lost during transmission, creating stutters or pauses in the video imagery, as in the video on the right. The more unstable it is, the more frequent pauses there will be in the imagery.


Audio stability


   

The fourth element, audio stability, is about how fluent the audio sounds. Even though these two video clips show the same imagery, the sound in the video clip on the right is choppier compared to the audio in the first video clip. That's because the video on the right has unstable audio, and hence you will miss parts of the audio.


Video-audio synchronization


Finally, the synchronization between audio and video imagery may also be impacted by limited internet bandwidth. Good synchronization allows the visuals in the video to match well with the sound. As the audio and visuals become out of sync, the visuals could appear ahead of the corresponding audio as shown in the video on the right.


   

Summary

In this study, we want to know how people prioritize their needs for these different video elements. These elements involve video resolution (how clear the visuals are), audio quality (how crisp the audio sounds), motion smoothness (how smooth the visuals are), audio stability (how fluent the audio sounds), and finally, the audio-video synchronization (how well the visuals and the audio match up).

Once you have read through this information and feel like you have understood the concepts, please click Submit to move on to the next page and take a small quiz about your understanding of these video elements.
